body:
## Steps to reproduce

```
kubectl run --generator=run-pod/v1 --restart=Never --rm -i -t test --image=mcr.microsoft.com/powershell:debian-10 --command -- pwsh
```

## Affected Distros

* Debian 10
* Debian 11
* Ubuntu 20.04
* Ubuntu 18.04

## Expected behavior

```
PS />
```

## Actual behavior

Outputs:
```
If you don't see a command prompt, try pressing enter.
PS /> `6C@@��D\@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@�]��@@`8@@@@ft.PowerShell_pr���������������� console is readinStop.InformatipStop:Powershell@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@7C@@@@@@@@@@C@@�0<\@@x�H�@@x��@@P6C@@����@@ 8C@�;\@@����@@����@@@8C@@����@@@
```

Another output is:
```
If you don't see a command prompt, try pressing enter.
PS /> ��1
>> @@@@ft.PowerShell_pr���������������� console is readinStop.InformatipStop:Powershell@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@�1
>> @@@@@@@@@@H�1
>> @@�05Y@@@�@@@�@@��1
>> @@����@@P�1
>> @�4Y@@����@@����@@0�1
>> @@����@@@��=Y@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@�]��@@`X�
```
It is posible backspace to delete all the chars.

It does not consistantly do this, but more often than not. 

This has been an issue since release of Powershell 7.0 IIRC.

## Workaround

### Disable PSReadLine

```powershell
kubectl run --generator=run-pod/v1 --restart=Never --rm -i -t test  --image=mcr.microsoft.com/powershell:debian-11 --command -- pwsh -NonInteractive
```

This indicates that psreadline is the issue.

### wait one second before launching pwsh 

NOTE: time may need to be increased to make this reliable

```
kubectl run --generator=run-pod/v1 --restart=Never --rm -i -t test  --image=mcr.microsoft.com/powershell:debian-11 --command -- bash -c 'sleep 1;pwsh'
```

comments.body:
Nevermind, here is the proper fix, call powershell as a login shell

```
kubectl run --generator=run-pod/v1 --restart=Never --rm -i -t test  --image=mcr.microsoft.com/powershell:debian-11 --command -- pwsh -l
```


comments.author: pcgeek86
comments.body:
Here's the easiest way to reproduce the issue:

1. Create Ubuntu Linux VM (on any cloud, or locally)
2. SSH into VM
3. Install k3s distribution of Kubernetes `curl -sfL https://get.k3s.io | sh -`
4. Run `sudo kubectl run --stdin --tty --image=mcr.microsoft.com/powershell pwsh01`
